content.webTitle: Claudio Ranieri happy for Leicester City to sacrifice control for goals

fields.headline: Claudio Ranieri happy for Leicester City to sacrifice control for goals
fields.bodyText: Claudio Ranieri has shrugged off criticism of Leicester City’s playing style, declaring he is happy for his team to sacrifice a degree of control so long as they play at a speed that unhinges opponents. Leicester have averaged only 42% possession this season, lower than any champions in the Premier League era, and they also rank low for other metrics including pass completion. But the Italian said anyone who uses those statistics to question the quality of the Premier League leaders is looking at the wrong figures. “Football is open, it is not only keeping possession of the ball and making more passes,” Ranieri said. “We make so many mistakes because we play at 100mph and it is difficult to play at 100mph. You can make mistakes. It’s not important how many mistakes you make, it’s about how many chances you create and how many goals you score. That is my philosophy.” Leicester’s ability to use players such as Jamie Vardy and Riyad Mahrez to spring forward with lightning pace has flummoxed most defences and is the chief reason why they have scored 54 goals in 31 Premier League matches – more than anyone except Tottenham Hotspur – and gathered more points than everyone else. Their position at the top of the table is a persuasive endorsement of Ranieri’s contention that Leicester’s style is the one that best suits their players and least suits their opponents. To Ranieri, that is the key to successful management. “What is important is to find the best solution for your players,” he said. “It is important to understand what your team can do.” One of the most dynamic players in Leicester’s team is the midfielder N’Golo Kanté, who has made such an impact since joining from Caen last summer that he was called into the France squad last month and made a scoring international debut in his country’s 4-2 victory over Russia on Tuesday. Kanté’s performances have also earned admiration from Europe’s top clubs and the player hinted in an interview while away on international duty that he might be open to a transfer in the summer. Ranieri does not believe the midfielder wants to leave but suggested he would not stand in his way if he were determined to go. “He should rest here,” the manager said. “He is working very well. But if some big teams come in for him, who give us a lot of big money, maybe we can think about it. If he is not happy here and wants to go … I don’t want sad people here. I want happy people.” Asked whether Kanté seemed sad, the manager replied: “No. He is always smiling. It’s just speculation.” Beyond individual players, the club as a whole is enjoying new status, as reflected by the invitation to participate in a friendly tournament in August – the International Champions Cup – against Barcelona, Paris Saint-Germain and Celtic. Ranieri said that fraternising with such illustrious names would help Leicester’s players prepare for next season’s European campaign. “It is important because we are in Europe now and are fighting to get there through the Champions League,” he said. “I want their minds open because not many players have played in Europe against the big teams. It is important to start thinking like a big team, a big club.” But not too big. Ranieri warned that if any of his players showed signs of becoming arrogant or complacent after this season, he would administer emphatic attitude adjustment. “If they change, I will take the hammer and break their heads,” the 64-year-old said with a smile before clarifying: “Change, yes, but change for the better.”
